) This IRM section provides procedures for working Joint Committee (JC) in the Appeals Division. (
) Purpose: The purpose of this IRM section is to provide guidance for cases subject to review by the Joint Committee on Taxation (JCT). (

) Audience: The primary users of the IRM section are Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs) working cases subject to review by the JCT. These employees include Appeals Officers, Appeals Team Case Leaders, and managers. (
) Policy Owner: The Appeals Policy Owner for this IRM section is the Case Operations and Support. (
) Program Owner: The Appeals Program Owner of this IRM section is Policy. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholder of this IRM section is the Joint Committee on Taxation (JCT). The JCT is discussed in IRM
) A refund or credit subject to Joint Committee review can arise from an nation, or tentative allowances in excess of the jurisdictional amount. (
) House of Representative’s bill (H.R.
) was signed by the President became law effective December
to increase the JC threshold for Corporations. The jurisdictional amount for C Corporations is in excess of million and for all other taxpayers the jurisdictional amount is in excess of million. (

) The JCT staff attorneys (also known as Refund Counsel) will review the Committee report and other documentation as deemed necessary. Should staff attorney have questions, they are usually resolved informally through phone calls or e-mails. In some instances, a written inquiry may be issued. the event the JCT disagrees with or questions the position taken in the the case is not ﬁnalized and remains open pending resolution of the ques- tioned items. The JCT will issue either a clearance letter or Staff Review Memorandum (SRM) upon completion of their review. (

) The Appeals Joint Committee Program Analyst (AJCPA) is responsible for: a. Updating the Joint Committee Program web page as needed b. Reviewing cases prior to submission to the JCT c. Responding to inquiries regarding speciﬁc cases d. Preparing monthly inventory reports Internal Revenue Manual
Purpose: The purpose of this IRM section is to provide guidance for cases subject to review by the Joint Committee on Taxation (JCT).
Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholder of this IRM section is the Joint Committee on Taxation (JCT). The JCT is discussed in IRM 8.7.9.2.
A refund or credit subject to Joint Committee review can arise from an exami- nation, or tentative allowances in excess of the jurisdictional amount.
8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines
See the table below for the most common acronyms in this IRM section:
) The Joint Committee on Taxation (JCT) is required by IRC Section

to vestigate: a. The operation and effects of the Federal system of internal revenue b. The administration of such taxes by the Internal Revenue Service; and c. Measures and methods for the simpliﬁcation of such taxes. (
) The JCT is also required by IRC Section

to publish for public tion and analysis, proposed measures and methods for simpliﬁcation of taxes, and to report to the Senate Finance Committee, the House Ways Means Committee, and, in its discretion, to the Senate or House of tatives, or both, the results of its investigations, together with such recommendations as may be advisable. (

) In carrying out its statutory responsibilities, the JCT is vitally concerned with learning whether the tax laws: a. Are being applied consistently with Congressional intent; b. Require clariﬁcation; and c. Grant unintended beneﬁts or cause unintended hardships. (

) The JCT is also concerned with learning whether the positions taken by the Service in Revenue Rulings, Regulations, and in litigation are consistent Congressional intent. The reports required of the Service, under IRC
, are a principal source of information for the JCT. (

) Excise and employment tax are not subject to JC review. Refunds on trust fund recovery penalty cases and windfall proﬁt taxes are also excluded from review by the JCT. (

) Every six months, each “selection area” (each numbered geographic designated area, the Domestic/International Operations function, and the of Large function) will submit reports to the JCT on the largest deﬁciency cases Cases for JC in that “selection area” by Appeals during that six month period. (
) The speciﬁc number of cases from each selection area will be designated by the Appeals JC Program Analyst (AJCPA), subject to approval by the JCT Senior Refund Counsel.

Note: If the largest deﬁciency cases closed are from the same office within the selection area, select the next largest cases closed from the other offices the “selection area.” No office will submit all selected cases from a selection area. The selection process will require coordination within the selection area. (
) The reports for the period ending March
will be submitted on or before last day of July, and the reports for the period ending September
will be submitted on or before the last day of January. (

) In considering what constitutes the largest deﬁciency cases closed for the month period, do not consider: a. An unagreed docketed case transferred to Counsel; b. An unagreed case considered in non-docketed status by Appeals then petitioned to and docketed in the U.S. Tax Court; c. A case that has been or will be reported to the JC as an overpayment case (overpayment cases should have a Feature Code of “JC” – cases with initially proposed deﬁciencies, in order to identify them and avoid duplicate reporting as a deﬁciency case); d. Special Enforcement Program (SEP) cases, including High Level Drug Leaders Tax Enforcement Project (DEP) cases; or e. Under reporter cases. (
) If a case is split with some years moving to a non-reporting category, the remaining in a reporting category will, at closing, be considered to the size of the case for reporting purposes. (
) Consider incoming deﬁciency amounts, not closing amounts, even if the determination is a refund. (

) If Compliance’s examination or survey action of the loss/credit source year(s) is completed before Appeals concludes action on its case, then Compliance will close its case to Appeals and send the return(s), RAR and administrative ﬁle to Appeals. Regardless of how Compliance resolves the source year(s) (surveyed, agreed, or unagreed and protested), the source year(s) should be forwarded to Appeals to be associated with the carryback year(s).
